ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned about different research methods and how to write and think about a research proposal.
I gained exposure to all the main sociological research methods and began to create concrete plans for my senior thesis project.
Introduction to sociological methods in the context of race.

I learned a lot about how various sociological methods work, as well as how to perform them myself. I also learned about how to take a research question and consider what method is the best approach to answer that question.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor Menon is a wonderfully engaging professor and was really flexible with deadlines and workload overall. The workload was very manageable, and it was really helpful to start receiving feedback on my thesis project ideas at the end of junior year.

Weaknesses: Cannot think of much other than that the readings were sometimes pretty dense and did not always directly relate to the content discussed during class.
Professor Menon and Kayla were great. I really liked the theme of looking at these methods through the study of race. I think this was a great way of making a required class much more engaging.

The strengths of the course were how organized they were, the fact that live Zoom classes were more discussion-based and helped us practice the things that we learned. Another strength was how clear the expectations were for every assignment.
I believe it would be interesting to incorporate other epistemologies into this class, such as Black Feminist Theory.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Menon and Kayla were really great at adjusting to the pandemic format. I liked the class discussions and lectures-- they were engaging and interesting but also respectful of student stress. Professor Menon was the only professor I had that actually asked how students were doing throughout the semester and adjusted the class to reflect the challenges of the semester. It was really wonderful feeling like she actually cared how we were feeling as students.

The in-class discussions were really interesting and helped us get a hands-on approach to sociological methods. The asynchronous recorded lectures were really great, as they helped reduce Zoom fatigue.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's a required class for sociology majors but also a really helpful research methods class for anyone in the social sciences/humanities. While the material may feel a bit dry at times, it's a very effective methods survey course and also allows you to start planning ahead for your senior thesis if you are a junior.
This class definitely felt a bit like a requirement, but Professor Menon made it much more engaging than I expected.
Yes! I would definitely recommend for anyone who is interested in doing practical research in the social sciences.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Also recorded lectures to watch before class
This class was sometimes a half-lecture, half-seminar, where Professor Menon would give a presentation for part of the time and lead a discussion for the other part.
